Description: Body sherd of Attic red-figured pottery cup; interior glazed black; exterior: red-figure decoration consisting of naked male figure moving to right (hips, groin and upper legs remaining; right leg almost frontal, left leg advanced); traces of dilute brown for minor interior markings.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of the Paris Gigantomachy (ARV 422, 104)
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Naukratis (according to G&R Department register)
Excavated/Findspot: Orvieto (Beazley Archive drawings show the fragment in the same batch as the Makron cup (Vase E63) and so it could well be from Orvieto.)
Curator's comments: The figure may have been a boxer like those on a number of other cups, see ARV2, 419, no. 32-4 and 46; Kyoto, Hashimoto coll. 75 in CVA Japan 1, pl. 2; Athens, Goulandris 271 in Marangou, L. I., Ancient Greek Art: The N.P. Goulandris Collection. Athens 1985, no. 142, a fact that illustrates well the repetitive nature of his work. The sherd was found unregistered in the British Museum in 1934, but a drawing in the Beazley Archive in Oxford, done for Hartwig, shows the fragment in the same batch as the Makron cup (Vase E63) and so it could be from Orvieto.
Bibliographic references: CVA British Museum 9 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 17, British Museum 9 (57 [p. 71 no. 57, pl. 80c])
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0704) (Phase 1)
